question:
Match list I and list II.

List-I

List-II

(a) Potential energy

(i) Solar thermal

(b) Chemical energy

(ii) Wind turbine

(c) Kinetic energy

(iii) Hydropower plant

(d) Radiation energy

(iv) Diesel generator

SSC CHSL Tier-II 02/11/23
solution:
Let’s match each form of energy from List-I with its most appropriate application/device from List-II:

  • (a) Potential energy → (iii) Hydropower plant
    • Water stored at height in dams has potential energy due to gravity. This energy is used in hydropower plants to generate electricity.
  • (b) Chemical energy → (iv) Diesel generator
    • Diesel contains chemical energy, which is released during combustion to generate electricity in diesel generators.
  • (c) Kinetic energy → (ii) Wind turbine
    • Wind has kinetic energy, which rotates the blades of a wind turbine to produce electricity.
  • (d) Radiation energy → (i) Solar thermal
    • Solar radiation is a form of radiant energy, used in solar thermal systems to heat water or generate electricity.

Correct Matching:

  • (a)-(iii)
  • (b)-(iv)
  • (c)-(ii)
  • (d)-(i)

Hence, the correct answer is:

Answer: d

question:
What kind of energy is associated with falling coconuts, speeding cars, rolling stones and flying aircraft?

SSC CGL Mains 26/10/23
solution:
• Kinetic energy is the energy possessed by a body due to its motion.
  • Objects such as:
    • Falling coconuts (moving downward)
    • Speeding cars (moving on road)
    • Rolling stones (rotating and translating)
    • Flying aircraft (moving through air)

All have mass and velocity, which gives them kinetic energy.

  • The formula for kinetic energy is:
  • KE = (1/2)mv², where:
    • m = mass of the object
    • v = velocity of the object

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Potential energy: Energy due to position or height, not motion.
  • (c) Radiant energy: Energy from electromagnetic radiation (e.g., light).
  • (d) Elastic energy: Stored energy in stretched or compressed elastic materials (like springs or rubber bands).

Additional Information:

  • As these objects are in motion, their energy is purely kinetic.
  • When an object falls, its potential energy converts to kinetic energy.

question:
If 7 N force is applied on a brick and it moves through 5 m, then what will be the work done?

SSC MTS 01/09/23 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Work done (W) is calculated using the formula:
  • W = Force × Displacement × cosθ
  • Here,
  • Force (F) = 7 N
  • Displacement (d) = 5 m
  • Since the force and displacement are in the same direction, θ = 0° and cos(0°) = 1
  • So,
  • W = 7 × 5 × 1 = 35 joules

Additional Information:

  • SI unit of work is joule (J)
  • 1 joule = 10⁷ ergs
  • If force and displacement are perpendicular (θ = 90°), then work done = 0

question:
When one stone is thrown upwards, what type of energy conversion would occur?

SSC MTS 12/09/23 (3rd shift)
option_1: Kinetic energy would change to mechanical energy
option_2: Potential energy would change to gravitational energy
option_3: Mechanical energy would change to kinetic energy
option_4: Kinetic energy would change to gravitational potential energy
solution:
• When a stone is thrown upwards, it slows down as it rises due to gravity.
  • The initial kinetic energy (due to motion) is gradually converted into potential energy as height increases.
  • This potential energy is specifically gravitational potential energy because it's due to height in Earth's gravitational field.
  • So, the correct energy conversion is:
  • Kinetic energy → Gravitational potential energy

Additional Information:

  • At the highest point, the stone's kinetic energy becomes zero and it has maximum potential energy.
  • Total mechanical energy (kinetic + potential) remains constant if we ignore air resistance.
  • This is an example of the conservation of energy.

question:
What type of energy conversion takes place in a battery?

SSC MTS 03/05/23 (Morning)
option_1: Chemical energy into light energy
option_2: Chemical energy into electrical energy
option_3: Mechanical energy into chemical energy
option_4: Chemical energy into sound energy
solution:
• A battery stores chemical energy in the form of reactants.
  • When the battery is connected in a circuit, a chemical reaction occurs inside it.
  • This chemical reaction releases electrons, which flow through the circuit as electric current.
  • Therefore, the correct energy conversion is:
  • Chemical energy → Electrical energy

Additional Information:

  • Batteries are used in torches, mobile phones, remote controls, etc., where stored chemical energy is converted into usable electricity.
  • This process is a form of electrochemical reaction.
  • Rechargeable batteries can reverse this conversion during charging.

question:
Which of the statements in NOT correct regarding energy?

SSC CHSL 14/03/23 (4th shift)
option_1: The energy possessed by a body due to its change in position or shape is called the potential energy
option_2:
An object of mass m moving with velocity v has a kinetic energy of
https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749723526261_image006.png
option_3: The gravitational potential energy of an object of mass, M raised through a height, H from the earth’s surface is given by MgH
option_4: An object in motion possesses what is known as the kinetic energy of the object
solution:
• Let's evaluate each option:
  • (a)Potential energy is the energy possessed by a body due to its position or shape → ✅ Correct
  • (b)Kinetic energy of an object of mass m moving with velocity v is given by:
  • K.E. = (1/2)mv²,
  • but option (mv/2) is incorrect → ❌Incorrect
  • (c)Gravitational potential energy is calculated as:
  • P.E. = mgh (or MgH) → ✅ Correct
  • (d) An object in motion possesses kinetic energy → ✅ Correct
  • Hence, option (b) is NOT correct.

Additional Information:

  • Kinetic Energy formula: (1/2)mv²
  • Potential Energy (gravitational): mgh
  • Energy is scalar and has SI unit joule (J)
  • Both kinetic and potential energy are types of mechanical energy

question:
The lifting of an object up and down, the parade of an army and the free fall of a heavy object are all examples of which motion?

SSC CHSL 01/06/22 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Let's examine the examples given:
    • Lifting an object up and down
    • Parade of an army
    • Free fall of a heavy object
  • All of these involve motion along a straight path:
    • When lifting or dropping an object, it moves vertically in a straight line.
    • Soldiers in a parade march in straight rows.
    • A freely falling object also moves straight down due to gravity.
  • Therefore, all these are examples of rectilinear motion, which means motion in a straight line.

Additional Information:

  • Rectilinear motion: Motion in a straight path (e.g., free fall, elevator motion)
  • Oscillatory motion: To-and-fro about a mean position (e.g., pendulum)
  • Rotational motion: Spinning around an axis (e.g., wheel)
  • Periodic motion: Repeats in equal intervals (e.g., Earth's rotation)

question:
The given equation describes the _______ relation.

s = u t + ½ a t2

SSC CHSL 03/06/22 (Morning)
solution:
• The given equation is:
  • s = ut + ½ at²
  • In this equation:
    • s = displacement or position
    • u = initial velocity
    • t = time
    • a = acceleration
  • This equation gives the position (or displacement) of an object after time t, when it moves with initial velocity u and constant acceleration a.
  • Hence, it shows the relationship between position (s) and time (t) → This is a position-time relation.

Additional Information:

  • This is one of the three equations of uniformly accelerated motion:
    1. v = u + at
    2. s = ut + ½ at²
    3. v² = u² + 2as

question:
Identify the correct formula to find the potential difference between two points.

SSC CHSL 06/06/22 (Morning)
solution:
• Potential Difference (V) between two points is defined as the work done (W) in moving a unit charge (Q) from one point to another.
  • The correct formula is:
  • V = W / Q
  • Where:
  • V = Potential difference (in volts)
  • W = Work done (in joules)
  • Q = Charge (in coulombs)
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • SI unit of potential difference is volt (V)
  • 1 volt = 1 joule / 1 coulomb
  • It is a scalar quantity
  • Measured using a voltmeter connected in parallel with the component

question:
Hydroelectric power stations generate electricity by using the force of water that falls into the turbines and spins the shaft. By rotating the shaft of the turbine, the potential energy of water is converted into _______ energy.

SSC CHSL 09/06/22 (Afternoon)
solution:
• In hydroelectric power stations, water stored at a height has gravitational potential energy.
  • When this water falls, its potential energy is converted into kinetic energy as it gains speed.
  • This kinetic energy is then used to rotate the turbine shaft, which drives a generator to produce electricity.
  • Hence, the correct conversion is:
  • Potential energy → Kinetic energy
  • Therefore, the correct answer is: (d) Kinetic

Additional Information:

  • Final conversion in the generator:
  • Kinetic energy → Electrical energy
  • This entire process is a form of mechanical to electrical energy conversion
  • No chemical or thermal energy is involved directly in this step

question:
Kinetic and potential energies of a body are the components of its ________ energy.

SSC MTS 18/10/21 (Evening)
solution:
• A body can possess kinetic energy (due to motion) and potential energy (due to position or configuration).
  • The sum of kinetic and potential energy is known as mechanical energy.
  • Hence, mechanical energy = kinetic energy + potential energy
  • So, kinetic and potential energies are the components of mechanical energy.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is: (c) Mechanical

Additional Information:

  • Kinetic energy: Energy due to motion → (1/2)mv²
  • Potential energy: Energy due to position or configuration → mgh (in gravity field)
  • Mechanical energy is conserved in ideal conditions (no friction or air resistance)

question:
Which of the following is an example of gravitational potential energy?

SSC CHSL 15/04/21 (Afternoon)
option_2: Bullet fired from a gun
option_3: Water that is behind a dam
option_4: Foot kicking a ball
solution:
• Gravitational potential energy is the energy stored in an object due to its height above the ground in a gravitational field.
  • The formula is: P.E. = mgh, where
    • m = mass
    • g = gravitational acceleration
    • h = height above ground
  • In the given options:
    • (a) Moving car → has kinetic energy, not potential
    • (b) Bullet fired from a gun → also has kinetic energy
    • (c) Water behind a dam is at a height and can fall → stores gravitational potential energy
    • (d) Foot kicking a ball involves application of force → kinetic or muscular energy
  • Therefore, correct example of gravitational potential energy is: (c) Water that is behind a dam

Additional Information:

  • When the dam gates open, water falls, converting potential energy into kinetic energy.
  • This is often used in hydroelectric power plants.

question:
Which of the following can do more work?

RRB ALP & Tec. 31/08/2018 (Shift-III)

RRB Group-D 12/10/2018 (Shift-II)
option_2: A bullet fired by the gun
solution:
• Among the options, a bullet fired by the gun can do more work because it possesses high kinetic energy due to its speed and mass.
  • A raised hammer has potential energy but less than the kinetic energy of a bullet in motion.
  • A moving stone and a rotating wheel also have energy but typically less capable of doing as much work as a bullet.
  • Therefore, the bullet fired by the gun can perform the most work.

Additional Information:

  • Work done is related to the energy transferred by an object.
  • Kinetic energy depends on the mass and the square of velocity.
  • This concept is important in physics and mechanical engineering.

question:
A force of 20 N displaces an object through 2 m and does a work of 20 J. The angle between the force and displacement is:

RRB ALP & Tec. 20/08/2018 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Diya gaya hai:
    • Force = 20 Newton
    • Displacement = 2 meter
    • Work done = 20 Joule
  • Work done force, displacement aur unke beech ke angle par depend karta hai.
  • Agar work done 20 Joule hai aur force displacement se 20 × 2 = 40 Newton-meter tak ka ho sakta hai, toh iska matlab hai ki force aur displacement ke beech ka angle aisa hai ki unka cosine 0.5 ho.
  • Cosine 0.5 ka matlab angle 60° hota hai.
  • Isliye, force aur displacement ke beech ka angle 60° hai.

Additional Information:

  • Jab force aur displacement same direction mein hote hain, angle 0° hota hai aur work maximum hota hai.
  • Jab angle 90° ho, force displacement ke perpendicular hota hai aur work zero hota hai.
  • Ye concept samajhna zaroori hai ki force kitna effective hai kisi object par kaam karne mein.

question:
A porter raise 12 kg object from surface of earthand put object 1.5 meter above from surface on his head. Calculate the work done on object-

(g = 10 ms-2)

RRB Group-D 04/10/2018 (Shift-I)
solution:
• A porter lifts a 12 kg object from the ground and places it 5 meters above on his head.
  • The acceleration due to gravity (g) is 10 m/s².
  • The work done is related to the force applied (weight of object) and the vertical displacement.
  • The force is the weight, which is mass × gravity, so here it is 12 × 10 = 120 Newtons.
  • Work done is force × displacement, which equals 120 × 1.5 = 180 Joules.
  • Therefore, the work done on the object is 180 Joules.

Additional Information:

  • Work done is the energy transferred to the object to raise it against gravity.
  • This calculation assumes lifting in a straight vertical path.
  • Understanding work done helps in physics problems related to energy and forces.

question:
Work done by a man standing on a platform holding 10kg suitcase is-

RRB ALP & Tec. 21/08/2018 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The man is standing still on a platform holding a 10 kg suitcase.
  • Since there is no displacement of the suitcase in the direction of the force applied (holding it steady),
  • The work done by the man is zero joules.
  • Work requires both force and displacement in the same direction to be done.

Additional Information:

  • Holding an object stationary does not involve mechanical work despite exerting force.
  • Work is done only when the force causes displacement.
  • This concept is fundamental in physics to understand energy transfer.

question:
A ball weighing 0.1 kilogram is dropped from a stationary position when it falls from a distance of 2 meters, then what will be the work done the force of gravity.

RRB ALP & Tec. 10/08/2018 (Shift-III)
solution:
• A ball weighing 1 kg is dropped from rest and falls through a distance of 2 meters.
  • The force of gravity does work on the ball as it moves downward.
  • Work done by gravity equals the force of gravity (weight) multiplied by the displacement in the direction of the force.
  • Weight = mass × gravity = 0.1 × 9.8 = 0.98 N.
  • Work done = force × displacement = 0.98 × 2 = 1.96 Joules.
  • Therefore, the work done by the force of gravity is 1.96 Joules.

Additional Information:

  • The work done by gravity is positive when the object moves in the direction of the gravitational force.
  • This work increases the kinetic energy of the falling object.
  • Understanding work done by forces is fundamental in mechanics.

question:
Capacity of doing work is known as-

RRB ALP & Tec. 31/08/2018 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The capacity to do work is known as energy.
  • Energy enables an object or system to perform work.
  • Power is the rate at which work is done, not the capacity itself.
  • Pressure and force are different physical quantities unrelated to the definition of energy.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is energy.

Additional Information:

  • Energy exists in various forms such as kinetic, potential, thermal, and chemical energy.
  • Understanding energy is fundamental in physics and engineering.
  • Conservation of energy is a key principle in science.

question:
It the value of work is positive then the kinetic energy of the body-

RRB Group-D 20/09/2018 (Shift-I)
option_2: Its value will be zero
solution:
• When the work done on a body is positive, it means energy is being transferred to the body.
  • This results in an increase in the kinetic energy of the body.
  • Positive work increases the speed or motion energy of the object.
  • Therefore, option (d) Increase his energy is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Kinetic energy is the energy associated with the motion of a body.
  • Negative work would reduce kinetic energy.
  • This concept is important in understanding energy transfer and mechanics.

question:
The work done by the force is positive when-

RRB Group-D 19/09/2018 (Shift-III)
option_1: Displacement occurs in the direction force
option_2: Displacement is perpendicular to the force
option_3: There is no displacement due to the force
option_4: Displacement occurs in opposite direction of force
solution:
• The work done by a force is positive when the displacement occurs in the direction of the force.
  • This means the force helps move the object in its direction, transferring energy to it.
  • If displacement is perpendicular or opposite to the force, work done is zero or negative respectively.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Positive work increases the kinetic energy of the object.
  • Understanding the sign of work is essential in physics and mechanics.
  • This concept applies to various real-world scenarios involving forces and motion.

question:
A porter lifts 500 N up to a distance of 100 meters work done by the porter is-

RRB Group D 06/12/2018 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The porter lifts a force of 500 N up to a distance of 100 meters.
  • However, if the porter is just holding the load stationary or moving horizontally without displacement in the force direction,
  • Then, the work done by the porter is zero because work requires displacement in the direction of force.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is 0 N (zero work done).

Additional Information:

  • Work is defined as force multiplied by displacement in the same direction.
  • If there is no displacement, no work is done regardless of force applied.
  • This is an important concept in physics related to energy transfer.

question:
In which of the following work is not done-

RRB Group-D 02/11/2018 (Shift-II)
option_1: A wind mill raising the water from well
option_2: A donkey put a weight on his back
option_3: Suman is swimming in a pool
option_4: A engine is pulling a train
solution:
• Work is done when a force causes displacement in the direction of the force.
  • In option (b), a donkey puts a weight on his back but there is no displacement caused by the donkey in the direction of the force exerted on the weight.
  • Hence, no work is done in this case.
  • Other options involve movement in the direction of force, so work is done there.

Additional Information:

  • Work = Force × Displacement × cos(θ), where θ is the angle between force and displacement.
  • If displacement is zero, work done is zero regardless of force.
  • This concept is fundamental in understanding energy transfer.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a unit of power?

RRB Group-D 24/08/2022 (Shift-I)
solution:
• Power is the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred.
  • Watt, joule per second, and horsepower are units of power.
  • Kilowatt hour is a unit of energy, not power.
  • Therefore, option (a) Kilowatt hour is NOT a unit of power.

Additional Information:

  • 1 watt equals 1 joule per second.
  • Horsepower is a traditional unit of power used mainly for engines.
  • Kilowatt hour measures the total energy consumed over time.

question:
How is power interpreted?

RRB Group-D 19/09/2018
option_1: Work done in energy transfer
option_2: Force charged to increase load
option_3: Working rate or energy transfer rate
option_4: Work done in a minute
solution:
• Power is interpreted as the rate of doing work or the rate of energy transfer.
  • It measures how quickly work is done or energy is converted.
  • Therefore, option (c) Working rate or energy transfer rate is correct.
  • Other options do not accurately define power.

Additional Information:

  • Power is measured in units like watt, which equals one joule per second.
  • Understanding power is essential in physics and engineering to evaluate efficiency.
  • Power helps compare how fast different machines or processes operate.

question:
Mohan having a mass of 40 kg. He climbs 50 steps of a staircase in 10s. If the height of each step is 15cm then what is his power?

(g = 10m/s2)

RRB ALP & Tec. 14/08/2018 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Mohan’s mass is 40 kg.
  • He climbs 50 steps, each of height 15 cm (0.15 m), in 10 seconds.
  • Total height climbed = number of steps × height of each step = 50 × 0.15 = 5 meters.
  • The work done is equal to the gravitational potential energy gained, which depends on mass, gravity, and height.
  • Power is the work done divided by time.
  • Calculating this gives Mohan’s power as approximately 300 watts.

Additional Information:

  • Power shows the rate at which Mohan does work climbing the stairs.
  • Gravitational acceleration g is given as 10 m/s² for calculation ease.
  • Understanding power in daily activities helps in studying energy expenditure.

question:
If a boy covers a distance of 20 meters with 600 Newton force in 4 minutes, then the amount of power consumed by the boy is?

RRB ALP & Tec. 29/08/2018 (Shift-II)
solution:
• The boy applies a force of 600 Newton over a distance of 20 meters in 4 minutes (240 seconds).
  • Work done is the product of force and distance.
  • Power is the rate of doing work, so work done divided by time gives power.
  • Calculating this, the power consumed by the boy is approximately 50 watts.

Additional Information:

  • Power indicates how quickly work is done or energy is transferred.
  • Time must be converted into seconds for standard unit calculations.
  • Understanding power helps analyze physical effort in activities.

question:
A boy of 50 kg mass climbs 40 stairs in 9 seconds. If the height of each stair is 15cm, then find his power.

(g = 10m/s-2)

RRB Group-D 23/10/2018 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The boy’s mass is 50 kg.
  • He climbs 40 stairs, each of height 15 cm (0.15 m), in 9 seconds.
  • Total height climbed = number of stairs × height of each stair = 40 × 0.15 = 6 meters.
  • The work done is equal to the gravitational potential energy gained, depending on mass, gravity, and height.
  • Power is the work done divided by time.
  • Calculating this gives the boy’s power as approximately 33 watts.

Additional Information:

  • Power indicates how fast work is done climbing stairs.
  • Gravitational acceleration g is taken as 10 m/s² for calculation ease.
  • This concept helps in understanding physical exertion in daily activities.

question:
Name the physical quantity that is equal to the product of force and velocity.

RRB Group-D 10/12/2018 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The physical quantity equal to the product of force and velocity is called power.
  • Power represents the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred.
  • Other options like work, energy, and acceleration have different definitions and formulas.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is power.

Additional Information:

  • Power is measured in watts (W) in the SI system.
  • It is important in understanding how quickly work is performed.
  • The relation Power = Force × Velocity applies when force and velocity are in the same direction.

question:
The average power is equal to which of the following?

RRB Group-D 25/10/2018 (Shift-II)
option_1: Total time taken/total used energy
option_2: Total free energy/total used energy
option_3: Total time taken/distance travelled
option_4: Total used energy/total time
solution:
• The average power is defined as the total energy used divided by the total time taken.
  • It represents how much energy is consumed per unit time.
  • Therefore, option (d) Total used energy / total time is correct.
  • Other options do not correctly describe average power.

Additional Information:

  • Power is the rate of doing work or transferring energy.
  • Average power is useful for understanding performance over a period.
  • It is measured in watts (W).

question:
If a girl with a weight of 40 N, climbs on the rope for 20 seconds with the power of 160 watts, then at which height will she reach?

RRB Group-D 18/09/2018 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The girl’s weight is 40 N.
  • She climbs with a power of 160 watts for 20 seconds.
  • Work done (energy used) = power × time = 160 × 20 = 3200 joules.
  • Work done against gravity is equal to weight × height climbed.
  • Therefore, height climbed = work done / weight = 3200 / 40 = 80 meters.

Additional Information:

  • Power represents the rate at which work is done.
  • The calculation assumes all power is used to climb vertically.
  • This concept helps in understanding energy expenditure and physical effort.

question:
A more powerful engine can do more work in less time lie an aeroplane travel more distance as compare to a car in less time. So aeroplane is more powerful than a car. It is an example of which of the following?

RRB Group-D 29/10/2018 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The example illustrates that a more powerful engine can perform more work in less time.
  • The airplane travels a greater distance than a car in a shorter time, showing it has more power.
  • Power is defined as the rate of doing work or energy transfer per unit time.
  • Therefore, option (b) Power is the correct choice.

Additional Information:

  • Power helps compare the efficiency and performance of machines.
  • Work performed and energy are related but do not account for time directly.
  • Understanding power is essential in mechanics and engineering.

question: Work done is said to be zero when
option_1: Force and displacement are in the same direction
option_4: Force is applied at an angle of 0°
solution:
• Work done is zero when there is no displacement.
  • Even if force is applied, if the object does not move, no work is done.
  • This happens because work involves moving an object through some distance.
  • For example, pushing a wall that doesn’t move results in zero work.
  • So, displacement is essential for work to be done.

Additional Information:

  • If force and displacement are in the same direction, work is positive.
  • Force being zero also means no work, but displacement is the key factor.

question: The unit of energy in the SI system is
solution:
• The unit of energy in the SI system is the Joule (J).
  • Energy is the capacity to do work or produce heat.
  • One joule is defined as the work done when a force of one newton moves an object one meter in the direction of the force.
  • Joule is a derived SI unit used to measure various forms of energy including mechanical, electrical, and thermal energy.
  • It is a standard unit used globally in science and engineering.

Additional Information:

  • Watt is the unit of power, which is the rate of doing work.
  • Newton is the unit of force.
  • Pascal is the unit of pressure.

question: A ball of mass 2 kg is dropped from a height of 5 meters. What will be its kinetic energy just before hitting the ground? (Take g = 10 m/s^2)
solution:
Potential energy at height = Kinetic energy just before hitting the ground.

PE = mgh = 2×10×5 = 100J

Hence, KE just before hitting the ground = 100 J.
